---
ID: 60
post_title: NUMA an overview
author: Amine
post_excerpt: ""
layout: post
permalink: >
  https://vrandombites.co.uk/2018/04/vsphere/numa-an-overview/
published: true
post_date: 2018-04-01 20:27:03
---
We all know that a CPU basic role is to process instructions that are fetched from slower components ie RAM. This introduces latency that will impact the CPU processing speed. This latency can be mitigated by the introduction of on-chip caches, however there are still times (cache miss) where the CPU has to wait for data.

Data read from RAM is transferred via a bus that is shared by all the CPUs on a system, the more CPUs, the more traffic the bus has to handle resulting in contention. Enter NUMA.

NUMA is computer memory design that breaks up a system into nodes of CPUs and RAM. The CPUs within a NUMA node will preferentially use their local RAM therefore minimising the problem of system bus contention.

Let’s take an example of a system with 6 sockets, each with 6 cores and 120G of RAM. Without NUMA 32 CPUs will have to contend for the use of the same system bus. With NUMA, we will end up with 6 NUMA nodes with local access to 20G of RAM each.

Looking at VMware 6.5 best practice guide, VMs running on NUMA nodes are divided into 2 groups.

<strong>VMs with less or equal to the CPUs in a NUMA node</strong>: Providing that the amount of allocated memory is less than the NUMA node memory, all memory and CPU resources are local to the VM and will preferentially be fetched from the local NUMA node.

<strong>VMs allocated more CPUs than the NUMA node (Wide VMs)</strong>: Will be split into multiple NUMA clients and each client assigned to a different NUMA node. A NUMA client could request memory access from a different non-local NUMA client node.

<a href="http://vsamurai.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/numa.png"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-66" src="http://vsamurai.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/numa-300x147.png" alt="" width="300" height="147" /></a>

Read more: <a href="https://www.vmware.com/techpapers/2017/Perf_Best_Practices_vSphere65.html">Performance Best Practice VMware vSphere 6.5</a>
